fact_list.fact_text: Before you reverse, make sure that there are no children or other pedestrians or obstructions in the blind areas behind you.
Do not reverse from a side road/minor road into a main road.
If your view to the rear is restricted, get help when reversing.
Pedestrians have the right-of-way at Pedestrian Crossings.
When approaching a pedestrian crossing, slow down and do not overtake other vehicles.
When approaching a pedestrian crossing, always be ready to slow down or stop so as to give way to pedestrians.
Signal to other drivers your intention to slow down or stop when approaching a pedestrian crossing.
Allow yourself more time to stop when the road is wet.
At a pedestrian crossing controlled by traffic signals or a policeman, give way to pedestrians who are still crossing even when the signal allows vehicles to move.
Stop when signalled to do so by a school patrol warden showing a 'STOP-Children' sign.
Watch for pedestrians who come out suddenly from behind stationary vehicles and other obstructions.
Pedestrians using rural roads tend to be less 'road-wise.'
When passing a pedestrian or cyclist, maintain as wide a distance as possible and drive slowly.
Slow down when driving across a muddy section of the road or through a puddle to avoid splashing muddy water onto pedestrians.
Ambulances ferry the sick and injured to hospitals.
Fire Engines help put out fires and Police Vehicles carry police personnel much needed in emergencies.
Obstructing the passage of emergency vehicles could mean the difference between life and death for someone.
If you encounter emergency vehicles with sirens or flashing beacon lights, give way by pulling in to the left or right side of the road depending on the circumstances.
Pull to the nearest edge of the roadway and come to a complete stop if necessary, until all emergency vehicles have passed.
Be alert to the approach of an emergency vehicle.
Switch on your direction signal when pulling off the road to send a message to the emergency vehicle operator that you are aware of their presence.
Do not block any intersection even when attempting to give way to an emergency vehicle.
Do not follow closely behind an emergency vehicle responding to an emergency.
Do not stop on a bridge, curve or crest of a hill; instead, proceed forward until you can safely pull over and come to a complete stop.
Do not slam on your brakes or stop directly in front of an emergency vehicle.
When driving, keep your attention on the road ahead, except for necessary and frequent glances at the rear view mirror, wing mirrors, and car panel.
Do not turn your head to talk to your passengers or to light a cigarette while driving.
Children should not be allowed to obstruct or distract the driver, and parents should train them not to do so.
Be careful when driving on steel plates laid on unfinished roadworks because these are extremely slippery, especially when wet.
Avoid driving through floods as there is a danger of brake malfunction occurring subsequently.
If driving through flood waters is unavoidable, pump the brake pedal repeatedly after emerging to dry the brakes.
